“Delay” is a word in desperate need of a memorable antonym in common use.
This happened to me when every game and movie I was looking forward to was getting delayed except one releasing next month in June, MonolithSoft/Nintendo’s Xenoblade Chronicles 3 was announced back in February originally stating that it’s releasing in September 2022, but was announced back in April to be on a solid release date of July 29, 2022.
Honestly, I have never heard of a major title getting this especially in the pandemic era that I was only speechless because I knew no word of the antonym to “delay”. I wouldn’t say “rushed” as in game development, especially with Nintendo and Monolith’s work ethics/philosophy, that they would rather keep a game on track if it’s still in development. Rather I suspect delays of many other titles gave room for the nicher AAA title to breathe in late July as Nintendo games can wrap up development quite a few months before release. “Expedited” is honestly a mouthful to remember, not to mention when it could mean a past-tense verb of “expedition” which I think of totally different things before I think antonym of “delayed”.

Time goes from the future to the past. We are moving from the past into the future. If we are heading north, time is heading south, like opposing traffic. If a meeting is pushed forward, it is forward in time, which means, further from the future into the past... thus it is earlier for us, it "jumped" forward towards the past. If the meeting was pushed back, it is pushed back into the future or "slowed down" from reaching the past. If we encounter a set-back in life, it means it will take more time for us to accomplish the task we were attempting, thus the time we will accomplish it was "pushed-back" into the future. This is not a hard concept to understand. Those that think pushed back means earlier, shouldn't be in charge of scheduling anything.

Remove the person from the equation, and it becomes objective. Follow the timelines rules, linear and forward. What is a timeline, tell people to draw it out. <del>--------------------------------> 123456789 or 987654321 <---------------</del>  That's what they will draw. There's no doubt about that. It doesn't matter which way the time line is going, because it's a linear line, you can draw it out however you want as along as the numbers increase in one direction. Ok so if you add a meeting into the equation,  123456/7/89 or 98/7/654321. Let's say the 7th will be that date and we want to move it forward by 2 days. On this line 123456/7/89 forward is <del>---> and on the other line 98/7/654321 forward is <----. So knowing that the line 123456/7/89 ----> is forward, so going forward would be going ----> and knowing that the line 98/7/654321 <---</del> is forward, so going forward would be going <----. Both examples are the same, going forward is going to the next date in the future. That's a fact of how time works. Just because you're facing a certain direction doesn't change how the timeline works. Forward is the same direction it always is + a day and backwards is - a day(amount of days is just an example). This is how you be objective. It's like someone telling you to use a chart and they don't follow the charts parameters, that's being subjective. Being subjective is wrong though, it's your false reality but reality is reality aka gravity is a force, humans die and 3+3=6, doesn't matter if you see if differently. Subjective is fine when it comes to emotional topics, such as emotional support though.

Edit: certainly there may be universals in communication, such as making sure how the langage communication has been received and is being perceived and understood.

Wednesday's noon meeting has been moved "forward" by 2 hours:
both you and time are facing each other at noon: you face toward 2pm and time is facing toward 10am

10am: you stay still (don't move), the time (noon) is moved through you to morning. Time is essentially moving backward.

2pm: the time is still (time cannot move back), so you have to move 2 hours from noon.

In this case I view the appointment at noon as a static position think a pillar on a time-line. So a point in time that I haven't reached yet. To move the pillar forward is to bring it closer to you, where as to push it back or push it away would be to make it further away.

The whacky thing is that both answers are correct - and it becomes more evident when you use the example of holidays. Holidays both comes to us as we go towards them. Time is always simultaneously moving forward as much as it is fading backward. The past and present and future is likely all happening all at the same time because 1 second ago was the past, 1 second forward is the future, and the mili/microsecond that you're experiencing right now is the present.

When time is so abstract, it's hard to not see it as an illusion of the mind, especially in science where sometimes our brains have been seen in certain case studies to perceive an incident milliseconds before the incident actually happens in real life time. Our brain processes time on a different level physically and mentally than something as concrete as a number or pattern of numbers that we know as time.

In German we would say:

- "2h vorziehen" (literally: to pull forth by 2h) --> 10am
- "2h nach hinten schieben" (literally: to push back by 2h) --> 2pm

So, the meeting is kinda like a solid object which is pulled and pushed on the timeline. "back" is something far away in this context (like background), so it's farther in the future. "forth" feels closer (like foreground), so it's closer to the present.

"forwards" in English only has the translation of "straight ahead" in German. So moving something forward always has the connotation of moving it in the direction in which you're heading. In time perspective, this is the future. I am moving forward on the timeline, and so is the meeting if I move it.

As for why I say moving the meeting forward would bring it to 10 am? Think of it on a scale. 10 am comes before 2 pm. Something moving forward would bring it ahead of something moving backwards. In a race, going backwards down the track brings you to those further from the finish while moving forward on the track brings you to those nearest the finish line. Also, compare it to Daylight Savings. As I was always taught, you Spring Forward when you set the clocks ahead an hour and you Fall Backward when you set them back an hour. Since our time keeping methods are human constructs and we are talking about things relative to the meeting, it is moving forward, coming closer, instead of moving backward, coming later.

A late comment, but I just wanted to say that in Chinese language, we have a very clear cut difference with the words 前, meaning forward in this context, and 后, meaning backwards in this context as well. We say 前天, which means the day before yesterday, and 后天, as the day after tomorrow. So my family uses forward to say that time has became earlier and then use backwards to say that time has become later. (The English in this sentence isn't really correct but it took the least amount of work to type out and be understood rather than misunderstood.) When I saw this question, I thought immediately of 10am. However, when watching movies and scrubbing through the timeline (I think I used an animation term for movies, which is not the best fit) I say 前 for scrubbing to the end, basically moving forwards, and 后, for moving backwards- getting back o the start. Not many people may see this comment, but if you do, my main point is: we might have different perceptions of time based on the situation and unit of it.

When referencing a meeting on a time line if you push a meeting BACK then you're adding on time to the countdown for said meeting, if you're moving it FORWARD, it's coming closer to the current time.

Therefore:
12 PM meeting moved FORWARD 2 hours is 10 AM
12 PM meeting moved BACK 2 hours is 2 PM

The words don't involve perception, it's a literal measurement based on our current qualification of a timeline.

I'm Italian, and me and my friends all think that it's at 2 p.m., but I think it's all about how you translate it: generally in Italian we have two words to translate "forward" in this context, one is "in avanti", and the other is "in anticipo", or the verb form "anticipare", and although they are semantically similar ("anticipare" has the same root of "anteriore", which means "the part of a thing that is "avanti", forward, ahead in space"), each word suggests a different perception of time: while the first suggests the ego-moving perception, the latter suggests the time-moving perception, and so the meaning of the two is opposite when speaking of time. For example when we switch from winter time to daylight savings time we say that "clock hands", meaning "the time", "are being moved "in avanti" by one hour", and when we switch the other way around we say that "clock hands are being moved "indietro" (back) by one hour", but "anticipare" (semantically similar to "avanti") an appointment by one hour has the same effect of moving clock hands back by one hour, and "posticipare" (the opposite of anticipare, semantically similar to "posteriore" which, you guessed, it's the opposite of "anteriore", and so it's the back part of a thing) an appointment by one hour has the same effect of moving clock hands forward by one hour.

I think it depends how often you've been in business settings, and how long you thought about the question.
I instinctively thought 2PM because of the word "forward". Thought of a clock, 12 being the top, forward being the right hand direction.
But I was thinking to quickly, when I thought about why it might be 10, I realised my error.
In a business setting, schedules are prioritised and full of things that need to be done in a particular order. When we talk about "moving" things forward or backwards, think about a set of cards with tasks to be completed in order front to back.
If you are asked to move things "forward in your agenda", you take the card in question (meeting) and bring it forward in priority (front). So it takes place earlier as it is more important "forward" by two hours.
If you were asked to move something "back" it would take place later on because it's further back in the agenda.

I don't really think that how you answer this question says anything about us or how we perceive time, as much as it does about how we approach language without totally clear instructions.
We can't "see" time, therefore we can't "see ourselves" moving through time in different ways, in my opinion. Time itself is a constant, from our human perspective at least.
How much time we feel has elapsed since certain events, and how long we feel we have to wait for things to happen is something that we can "feel" different about in our brains though. Based on our estimates of how long increments of measured time take, in the case of when our shift ends for example. How many memories were formed during and after certain events, how long months and years feel to us, and how old we are will make us feel different about how long ago things were. We may feel like the first half of our shift at work flew by, but the second half is taking forever (despite them being the identical length of time on the clock). Or we may feel like the birth of a family member feels like only a couple of years ago, despite them being a teenager now. Years feel like a smaller amount of time the older we get as fractionally they become a smaller percentage of your life year after year.

This is interesting to me, because my first thought when encountering the phrase "the meeting has been moved forward" was that it was at 2pm, but I can definitely see how someone could see it as being at 10am instead. Upon thinking about it more, I found myself analyzing how I would react to related phrases. If someone told me "the meeting has been moved up" I would think the meeting was at 10am. If told "the meeting has been moved back" I would think 2pm. Thinking on my conundrum further, I realized that most of the time I've heard someone talking about moving a specific event closer, they have been talking about making the event sooner, exe. "we moved the wedding forward from the 12th to the 10th" whereas if they go the other way, I hear them saying "we've pushed the wedding back from the 13th to the 14th" and this makes total sense to me, which is likely why I associate "moved back" with a later time. I wonder if it was because we were dealing with hours that my first reaction was opposite to this, and I wonder if it's because while I was growing up, I was taught "spring forward" and "fall back" to know how to adjust my clocks for daylight savings time. In the spring, I "spring forward" by adding an hour to the clocks, and I "fall back" by subtracting an hour from them. If this is true though, then I wonder why I associate "fall back" with subtracting hours, and "pushed back" with adding them. If anyone has any thoughts as to why I might think this way, please share them with me.

I have the most boring type of synesthesia but it's actually relevant for this. I blend time and space perception, which is what I though everyone did until I heard about time-space synesthesia and realized that not everyone does that. For me, time is like a helix/coil that I'm standing on, with the future being up, forward, and to the right, and the past is down, forward, and to the left. When I'm thinking of time relative to myself, I see it based on wherever I am on the coil. When I'm thinking of time relative to itself (like thinking of a date on the year, but not how far away it is from me), I'm standing in the spring, around April, probably because that's when my birthday is. So from that standpoint, I'm in the spring, summer is to my right, winter is to my left, and autumn is below and across from me. But right now it's November, so winter is to my right, summer is to my left, and spring is up and across from me. Seasons also have colors but I think that's just kind of cultural, like spring is green, winter is ice blue, fall is dark orange and summer is yellow. But I think that's just the colors most people associate wih the seasons.

There is no objective measure of time. We only measure the order of things by comparing them to the order of other things. We don't measure a runner against time, but against the movements of a second hand on a watch. There is a sequence of events, which we label as time, but time in and of itself, doesn't exist. It is a linguistic (and therefore mental) construct upon which our thoughts are so dependent that it is nearly impossible to exclude.

I think the systems are a misnomer and the names should be switched for the modes of time perception. Hear me out!

Ego-moving perception should mean you think events happen relative to YOU… so if you believe moving a meeting forward brings it closer to your current position in time, well, that’s ego.

Whereas if you believe a meeting has been moved forwards and is 2 hours later than originally scheduled… well, that means your understanding of time is that everything moves forward through time and the meeting is shifted forwards in time relative to the meeting’s perception of time itself. That is to say, this is an objective view of time, no ego.

This is a total misnomer!

I’ll throw in one final weapon to support my argument: Any time travel movie in Science Fiction refers to travelling to the past as “going back in time”. That means shifting anything I to the direction of the past is moving BACK in time. To suddenly invert the accepted definition of moving things (or people) “backwards” and “forwards” in time is to surrender an objective view of the space-time continuum and suddenly shift into an ego-centric view where time moves around you and events shifting towards your existence in space time means things are moving forwards towards… *you*.

Again, total misnomer!

And now to add my two cents worth… the so-called ego-moving perception is absolutely, objectively the correct perception of time-scheduled events!

It actually makes quite a bit of logical sense the way the indigenous people of Aymara think of the future as behind them and the past as in front of them. Think about it like this for a moment: the future is completely unknown. All we can "see" in terms of memory or reliable visualization is the past, and any future that is "100% known" is in a sense, past.
Our eyes point forward, we only see what's in front of us, and if we ignore the idea of "moving through time" for a moment, and consider the fact that we can only see the past, not the future, it then actually makes more sense for the past to be in front of us and the future to be behind us.

In the industrial-obsessed west we're very highly concerned with time though, so it makes sense that our perception of time & motion through time would take that sort of cognitive precedent.

When we walk from one place to another, we walk forwards, we don't walk backwards. When we arrive somewhere by walking forward time has also gone forward so the place we used to be is in the past, behind us, and where we are now once we arrive, the present was in front of us. It may also depend on the languages people speak in relation to English.
In Spanish, the verb "adelantar" refers to moving an event closer to the present, while the verb "atrasar" means moving an event further to the future.
"Adelantar" comes from the adjective "adelante" meaning forward or in front. "Atrasar" comes from the adjective "atrás", meaning behind or in the back. I’ve seen some people say something like this and I agree. The way I see it, I always learned that a meeting could be a.) pushed back or b.) moved up. I don’t know why I learned the two directions would be up or back and not down or forward but whatever. If the meeting is moved up then it becomes earlier (10am), like when reading a schedule in english it’s written with the earliest times at the top and gets later to the bottom. If it’s pushed back it is then later in the day (2pm), I’ve often heard, “we have to push our meeting, (dinner, movie time, etc.) back because I’m running late.” Or whatever. Eitherway. If someone said moving a meeting “forward” I would first ask because to me personally that is a weird way to phrase that. But left to my own devices I would assume they meant 10am because “forward” is the opposite of “back”. And I’d hate to show up at 2pm to find out I’m 4 hours late if I was wrong. I'm not a native English speaker, so it took me quite a while to understand the problem here. In my language, when you talk about moving an event, the word you use to describe it specifies whether the event will occur later or earlier. That doesn't leave much space for subjectivity, so when you talked about "forward" I automatically thought "forward is +, so +2 hours". Because time is less subjective in my language, I thought about "forward" as either + or - time, instead of as moving in correlation to something else (which is a more subjective type of progression). I hope that makes sense🤔

Edit: now that I think about it, you'll actually need to give more information about the situation in Hebrew to make time subjective, which is pretty weird. Giving more info will let you use more subjective words that give the same perspective as "forward".

What do you think when someone says "there will be dinner followed by a wedding"? Does dinner happen first, or does the wedding happen first? The two ways I understand to look at this is "which one happens first" and "which one is listed first on the calendar." If dinner is shown before a wedding on a calendar, the dinner visually follows the wedding. But in terms of time, the thing that follows is the thing that happens AFTER the first thing, which in that case would be the wedding.

I defy the notion that my perception is limited by language. I regularly create new words and expressions that help to convey my generally atypical way of thinking which confuses most, hence the necessity for me to create new expressions of such.

I perceive time as a dimension of space, which I as a physical being am already spread throughout, and the only thing which moves is our awareness through our physical selves spread across time, and contrary to popular belief, the movement of that awareness does not simply "move forward", but rather exists independently of our notion of time and takes motion through whichever point it needs to be in; That is to say, neither I nor time itself is moving, and any appearance of motion is purely an illusion of perception, because time itself IS motion. It's like the "is water, wet?" Question, the asking defeats the purpose of the descriptor.

If someone says, "the meeting has been moved up", that to me, linguistically, doesn't sound as if someone is trying to say that it was moved "ahead in the day", but rather, to a point in time which is relatively sooner; in short, grammatically, that is an inference towards 10am, but coloquialism, habit, and dialect can all affect that, so trying to mandate that one perception or the other implies a specific view of time is rather anglocentric of you.

Imagine I told you that in two hours, a building would be destroyed; a second later, two timezones over, a building collapses, and I have told the truth, because the time the incident would be recorded at would be two hours later relative to us, but the intervening time isn't truly time, but physical space. In truth, two hours "forward" from our point of reference and two hours "forward" in time zones are very different things, both from a graphing and measuring standpoint as well as actually physically speaking, but given the framework of our culture and language, they are the same thing, a fact which should deeply disquiet you, because you should know the difference is truly relativity.
If you allow your perception to be chained to language, you doom yourself to never being able to see more than you already know. We shape words, they do not shape us, and if you allow them to, you allow yourself to be manipulated.

I love you guys, but this is a bit... much. I’m an editor and this is just one way in which we can see English is a language that can be very sloppy. Without more specificity or context, there are two ways to construe the sentence.

Here’s another:
(Let’s say it’s Monday.)

I want to get together with my family next weekend.

Now, does that mean the next weekend occurring on the calendar? At the end of the week? Or not the very first weekend that passes and the weekend belonging to next WEEK instead?

This has nothing to do with perceptions of the world or how you view yourself, but the relative lack of specificity that many people use when speaking English. Spanish, for example, has ways to indicate if “those windows” means those windows next to someone else or those windows that are further away without having to add, “all the way over there.” It’s in the word choice itself that you gain context.

After reading some comments, I feel like the 10am vs. 2pm problem is more about linguistic perception than a temporal one. People interpreted "move forward" differently because it seems like there are different ways to interpret what that could mean. If phrasing like "move up" or "pushed back" was used, their answer would change. I'm in the 2pm boat, because I contrasted "move forward" with "move backward", so in that sense the only answer I thought it could be is 2pm. But if the meeting was in fact moved to 10am, I would have rather said "moved up" which is generally understood by English speakers to be moved  to an earlier time. Besides, there's no such thing as a time that's "moved down", so I wouldn't have had this 10am vs. 2pm dilemma. But interesting video nonetheless!

To me, this question is more about language and less about time perception. That said, time flows at the same rate (1second/second) and in the same direction regardless of any individual's action. The reality, regardless of our perception, is that both cases are simultaneously true: we are moving through time as it moves around (and independent of) us. In the same way that we move infinitesimally upon the Earth while the Earth chases the Sun in a spiral path at breakneck speed and the Sun similarly chases the supermassive black hole at the center of the Milky Way and on up and up and up. For me, it just seems logical to assume that by saying the meeting was “moved forward”, the implication is that the meeting was moved toward the future as we (English speakers) see time moving in one direction: from past to future. If the saying was rather “the meeting was moved forward towards you”, the implied time would objectively be 10am.

I notice this also happens when people don't use specific dates for making plans. For example, if a person says on July 5th (which is a Sunday) "I have an appointment next Tuesday",  some people will think "next Tuesday" means July 7th as that is the Tuesday that will occur next, but others will see July 7th as "this Tuesday" which would make July 14th "next Tuesday".

This reminds me of the “Sapir-Whorf hypothesis” which the movie “Arrival” was centred around. The Sapir-Whorf Hypothesis suggests that people’s thoughts are shaped by their language, so two people speaking different languages may perceive the same thoughts completely differently. This is called linguistic relativity. There are some criticisms to this hypothesis but nonetheless, really cool.

If I said I travelled back in time, everybody would assume I travelled to the past. If I instead went forward in time, I travelled to the future. Therefore if the meeting moved forward in time, it should be at 2pm.

One thing in the English language that always throws me off for a moment is the use of the expression "half eight" to mean 8:30. I always have to consciously convert my initial perception of the stated time from 7:30 into 8:30, and that's because even though I'm fluent in English, my first language was German, and in German when you say "halb acht" ("halb" = "half" and "acht" = "eight"), you mean half of the eighth hour of the day, or halfway through the eighth hour, half of the way from seven to eight. When you say "half eight" in English, you're shortening "half PAST eight", and leaving out the very useful "past", as in, half past the eighth hour of the day. If English-speakers could please say, "half past eight" from now on, that would help this German Kiwi, thanks!

Obviously time is moving independent of us. Does your clock not move while you are standing still? I think this has less to do with perception of time and more with what people mean when they verbalize statements about time.

Ego moving perception: Forward meaning forward on the clock. So if someone says 2 hours forward 12(noon) they will think 2pm. Now let’s use the opposite. Pushed back. The meeting has been pushed back 2 hours. They will think the meeting is now pushed back 2 hours from 12(noon).

Time moving perception: In this instance, forward to them is when the time is coming towards or away from them. If you were to stand on a ball, you have to walk forward in order to move backwards. That’s how time moving perception works. To them, forward means to come closer, and pushing back means to get further. Because they aren’t the ones moving with the time. The time is coming and going for them. Just like the video itself says.

I just finally figured it out! So when someone says the meeting is moved forward from noon by 2 hours, I think of 2 pm. But I can see how others would say it's 10 am, because if time is coming towards you then the meeting just got closer to you by 2 hours so it's 10 am. So here are two analogies, 1. This is how you could describe the 10 am people. They think that they are a stick stuck in the mud while a river(time) moves around them. Think of the meeting as a boat floating down the river, so when you move the boat (meeting) forward in time the boat would be getting closer to you(the stick), you could say the boat was moved forward in time. 2. Now using a similar analogy, think of the stick as the meeting and yourself as the boat and time is still the river. You are rowing up the river(the river is flowing against you) to get to the stick (the meeting) , but now it has been moved forward by the river(time), so now it is further away from you and it will take longer for you to get to it.
I hope this helps someone!!

I have 4 things to say:
-My reasoning for why it's 2:00pm
-Claimed Reasoning for 10:00am
-Counter for 10:00am Reasoning
-Conclusion

My reasoning for 2:00pm:
If you move backwards in time, you are going to the past.
If you move forward in time, you are going to the future.

Claimed counter for 10:00am:
If the meeting is moved back, it is moved back to 2:00pm. If it is moved forward, which is the opposite of back, it is moved to 10:00am

My counter to 10:00am:
People are saying that the opposite of forward is back. That is wrong. The opposite of forward is backward. Now that we know the actual opposite of forward, we know that moving backwards in time is going to the past, and moving forward in time is going to the future.

Conclusion: In my opinion it is 2:00pm, I'd love to hear more arguments from others. I ask you to not only say your own reason, but also counter my reasoning. Thanks.

...so at first I thought "Yeah, the meeting moved forward, as I am moving forward, it's obviously going away from me".
But I can totally understand that people can have the exact opposite interpretation, considering the meeting is "coming closer" hence it moving "forward" means "towards me" and therefore the meeting will be sooner.
With that in mind, I wouldn't consider it a general different conception of time and more a different interpretation of the word "forward" in the context of time. Unlike the dress or Yanny/Laurel, the issue is based on the concept of "interpreting the meaning of words within a context" and hence not necessarily outsourced to the subconsionsness. So it can actually change based on basic expiriences especially those within the shortterm-memory (like being on a train or plane). Surely a similar effect could be seen when reading about the "sun" while being on a holiday (and associating it with sunbathing on the beach -> relaxing, good) or during a week of hard work (and associating it with the working-hours -> dreaded, exhausting). Given the context, the brain creates a base-interpretation with lower brain functions, while we technically can use higher brain functions the question that interpretation and come to a different conclusion, if we think about it. Meanwhile I have never managed to look at that damn dress and see it as any other but white/gold.

Also the more I think about the question, the more it seems obvious that "moved forward" refers to "a sooner time on the clock" hence 10am.

Only one sidewalk is moving, but which one is irrelevant - the end result is that you are moving toward each other at a steady pace of 1 meter per second. This means you will meet/pass each other at the 12 second mark. Then Time suddenly jumps forward by two meters. This means that you will now meet/pass each other at the 10 second mark. I thought about it and came up with this.

Say you print out a version of the schedule and say to everyone "Hey! Wednesday's noon meeting has been moved forward by 2 hours!". I think you're giving an update on a change that happened JUST NOW (recently) as of the printing of the schedule and the event (the time change) shall take place / take effect in the future.

OR

You are giving the update in reference of an old version of the schedule and saying that the new version is the most up to date. Saying that the time change has already taken place BUT the update was just given right now.



So I think I saw both sides at the same time. Thanks for coming to my TEDTalk. :)

Interesting. In English, as I heard it in the video, I thought of 2 p.m. too. But if I heard essentially the same thing in my mother tongue, Hungarian: "két órával előrehoztuk a meetinget", I would think of 10 a.m. . Why? Because in English it was phrased as "[the] meeting has been MOVED forward" - this, to me, implies moving stg (outside of myself) forward (from my perspective - "my forward"), so +2 hours. However, the Hungarian phrasing uses "előrehoztuk", which literally means "we've BROUGHT it forward" - and, well, if you BRING stg, then that already determines the direction: you're bringing it this way, towards me, so -2 hours.

I had to think about this, because in German we say most of the time, that a meeting is two hours earlier or two hours later. Or it is „vorverlegt“ (it’s closer to you) or „nach hinten verschoben“ (it‘s further away) in relation to your position on a time scale. But my first reaction was 2 pm because if you look forward on a time scale (into the future) it is now two hours more forward than it already was. But I totally understand people who say 10 am, because the German „vor“ like in „vorverlegt“ is related to „vorne“ wich is a direction and „nach vorne“ can also mean forwards (sounds almost like „vorwärts“ and has also the same meaning). So from the meetings point of view, wich is heading in my direction, „forwards“ is towards my position, so that can result in 10 am. But normally there is only a small ambiguity in the German language if a meeting is earlier or later if the time has changed. Only when it comes to daylight saving time nobody seems to know whether we set the clock forwards or backwards. 😉

Here’s my problem: when I hear “wednesdays noon meeting has been pushed forward two hours”, I think 2 pm. But when I hear “wednesdays meeting has been pushed BACK two hours” I also think it’s at 2 pm. I think the reason why I think this way, is because both ways of phrasing this kind of thing are used, but in almost every context most meetings are delayed rather than expedited. Since both perspectives are relative neither is correct, so rather than have to rely on context cues, people should use the words after/before because then it fixes the perspective to be in terms of the event (ie ego moving perspective). For example, no one will confuse the phrase “wednesdays noon meeting is taking place 2 hours after its previously scheduled time”.

I kind of feel like the Ego moving perspective doesn't make sense to  someone who  is a native german  speaker. (Although that could also just be me). Because for that to work, you have to perceive time from the perspective of the meeting. Behind the original time is the past, so if you move forward, you move further into the future.  But I think in german you view this shift from your own perspective. If it is closer in time to me, it is before the original time. Moving the meeting forward means moving it closer to me and the original time is later and  therefore behind it. A meeting doesn't have agency. If a person, however, would time travel and move forward two hours, it would be 2 p.m., because they are the reference point for time, which an inanimate object just can't be.

This is similar to an issue I had. I thought the newer stone age came earlier than the old stone age. This is because I saw it from the perspective of the planet, not us humans. The planet was younger during the early stone age, and older during the later stone age.

However, from the "correct" (human-centered) perspective, the earlier stone age happened further back in time, therefor its older, while the later part occured more recently therefor its newer.

Today I can see why we use the second perspective. It also makes way more sense during our short lifespan. If a house was built 50 years ago, we see it as old. While if it was build 5 years ago, we see it as new. Therefor our accepted frame of reference to time is that we don't move forward through time, time move backward through us. Since we see ourselves as the centerpoint.

I was taught this is the difference between a meeting being "moved" forward and being "brought" forward. As the future (at least for me culturally) is forwards, to be moved further in that direction is to be made later. However, to be brought something is to make it closer to my current position and so is to be made earlier.

I think this all comes down to the clunky designs of our brains. They were never designed to understand time and evolution is a slow process so it used what was already there: a fundamental understanding of space. That's why we talk of time as 'forward' or 'backward' in the first place. We can't 'move' through time in the same way but we use a one-dimensional representation (for the most part) to try and make sense of time. And because this design is built on the mechanisms for spatial navigation, we feel a desire to 'move toward' things in the future that we look forward to, much the same as you would physically move toward a bush of tasty berries in the wild.
Couple this with our brains' tendency to fool themselves to seem better and more in control, and we get the opposite effect too. If we dread something in the future, we don't want to move toward it, and since we consider ourselves in control of our actions, we perceive ourselves as not moving toward it.
In a spatial representation, the only thing that makes sense is that IT is moving toward us. And if something you don't want (like a predator) appears to be moving toward you, your bound to feel anxious about it. But since you can't move backward through time, you're stuck feeling helpless and maybe trying to prolong the time before it comes.

For me as a non-native English speaker it's quite interesting: in English I would perceive the time as 2 PM. I even checked it in the dictionary afterwards and in English it seems "forward" is always used for the future. But if I heard the same statement in my mother tongue, I can imagine it both as 10 AM, as well as 2 PM, so it would be confusing to me without any context. 😂 I checked in the dictionary and it seems in my language (Bulgarian) "forward" is more used to mean "earlier", although there are also some examples of when it is used to mean "into the future" (more in a figurative sense when the outlook / movement in space equates with time). So this explains my confusion in my mother tongue (combined with the different perspective from Engish) haha! I guess the 10 AM perspective has more to do with how close something is to the present, the present determining the "direction" of time. If something is moving closer to the present, it is then deemed "forward" regardless whether it is coming from the past or the future. "Backward" would then mean further away from the present. Whereas the 2 PM perspective always has it that "forward" is the future and "backward" is the past regardless of where the present lies (like in the Aymara language you mentioned). 🤔

I took a class of Aymaran culture at uni (2:16) and their time perception is mind blowing.
Past is perceived to be in front of one bc one knows it (one can only know what one has seen), and thus can "see", what happened in the past.
However, future is unknown, and thus cannot be "seen" (just like anything behind one), and therefore it is perceived as something "behind".

Also, their perception would be closest to time-moving, as the future - moving from behind towards one's front - goes from unknown (what one cannot see) to know (what one can see, bc it's in front of one).
We americans are obsessed with duality!

Fun fact: in Spanish, you can say the meeting has been moved forward (se ha ADELANTADO) by two hours and everybody knows it's gonna be at 10am. But there is a similar expression (se ha programado para más ADELANTE) which means something like "the meeting has been set in a more forward date" and everybody understands it is 2pm.
Same word root, in fact, but completely different meaning and yet everybody knows what that means. The subject of the sentence is different and that sets a different point of reference for time. Either we move forward into the timeline of future, or the meeting itself is moving forward into us, getting closer in time.

This entire video is silly/stupid. An event being moved forward/up means it is being moved closer, so in the example given it would be at 10 AM--2 hours earlier than the original noon.
However, when we move the clock itself forward, we advance it. [A small phrase for DLST that's passed around in my family at least, is "spring forward, fall back", to help as a way to remember which way to adjust the clocks for DLST]
This is likely where some of the confusion arises in people as they blur the line, and also forget linguistical context clues and understanding. The other way to look at it is, if it's been moved forward, you are to advance toward it--ie, you will reach it sooner. If it is moved back, it has been delayed.

I'd really like to see this explained for people who are multilingual like me.
I think closest to the time moving perception, BUT thanks to the fact that I speak 4 other languages, the whole thing is topsy turvy. Specifically learning Mandarin has altered the way I perceive things, and in a drastic way. You say, "The meeting has been moved up 2 hours," and I think the meeting is now at 2pm, but not because I think that time is coming at me (though I am more likely to say that the holidays are coming at me.) It's because in Mandarin, time isn't perceived as left and right, it's perceived as up and down where down is the past and up is the future (so time is always moving up.)
So like, in Mandarin, when you say "next week," you say "下个星期." The first character, 下(xia) means up. So basically the phrase is "up week." And to say "last week" is "上个星期." The first character, 上(shang) means down, so "down week."

At first I thought 2 pm, but then after asking Getting a second opinion I made sense of and now think, if not know, it would be 10 am. Here's why.

Do you control time or does time control you? Time controls you because we cannot ever travel into the future or even the past. We can only ever be in the present. We can make time appear to be moving faster, but can never actually travel through time. We can't control time because time isn't something we can interact with. It's a fundamental part of reality. Another thing is, we can control things within time, but we cannot control time itself.

The problem is, this doesn't quite explain why time is moving forward through us. We are moving in time, but time mus be moving through us because we aren't moving through time. Another way to look at it is with a rock, to the rock things are just happening, has no goals or hobbies or anything really other than it exists. Yet it's travelling through time. We are the same way. We do stuff and think stuff, but other than that the only difference between us and the rock is that we are conscious living things. For this reason, time comes to us, not the other way around. Thus, time moves through us.

Since time moves through us, time must also be moving forward through us because otherwise that would imply we are about to experience is the future, which is impossible to be the case, by definition. Thus, the answer to the question must be 10 am since the time is moving forward.

My first reaction is 2pm - but this is the type of thing where if I thought about it or someone said 10am I would go "oh.... shoot, I misunderstood". It is all about the relative framework you choose and what "forward" means - is "forward" in time (a nonsense term if I ever hear one if you really think about it - time has no spacial element that lets you go forward or back or left or right or up or down) meaning moving closer to you or away from you? What relative frame is your "forward" - and when you think "up the street" do numbers on the houses increase or decrease? (In that case, it may be up as in the number values go up to the top of a rank ordering, where #1 is the first number; or the values get bigger or go "up" in total value and are greater than the prior numbers).

So in the end, I think of forward in time following times arrow, as nothing going forward in time can move against the flow of time and thus be earlier... time to us is perceived as a stream that can only flow one direction, and the further away from me is the further foward along time's arrow. However, I can see people viewing it as the rank ordered system - where earlier is "forward" because time is perceived like a queue, there those that come first are at the front or forward in line and get to do whatever first.

In the end, I'll just say saying a meeting is moved without stating an explicit time rather than a relative time is a horrible thing to do in a language as ambiguous as English - but then again, that's upper management for you.

okay I have two things to say. first of all, as you explained the concepts further, the more I could understand both of them. when the question was initially asked my answer was 2 pm, but if someone said to me "Wednesday's meeting has been moved UP two hours" instead of "moved FORWARD two hours" I might think the new time was 10 am instead, which is now making me question everything about my life. secondly, physical descriptions of time are a HUGE and crucial part of American Sign Language (ASL). in ASL there are no past and present tenses for words. if you wanted to sign "last weekend I went to the gym." you would sign "past" by swishing your hand backwards over your shoulder, and then the normal sign for "weekend" before continuing with the sentence. and if you wanted to sign "next weekend I'm going to the gym" you would first sign "future" by moving your hand out and away from your head in an arc-like motion, and then continue with the sign for "weekend." In ASL you can also use the "past" and "future" signs to say something like "a long time ago" by swishing both hands backwards over your shoulder (sometimes with an exaggerated facial expression depending on how long ago you mean) or something that won't be happening for a very long time by making the sign for "future" but extending the arc-like motion even farther away from you, and even making more than one arc as your hand moves farther out.

Sounds related to Kahneman's book "Thinking, fast and slow" I would say you are both wrong because you are both applying what is called the attribute substitution also known as the substitution bias. One of you may be visualising the hands of a clock being moved forward or back that may or may not be what the person resetting the time for the meeting was visualising. The MIND does not think in words alone. Anyway when considering time from a point in time that has happened, including the present, one can talk about about "back in time" and "forward in time" very clearly without ambiguity. However when considering time from a point in time that has not happen, such as the appointed time for a meeting, one should talk about "sooner in time" or "later in time" to avoid ambiguity. So when resetting the time for a meeting that has not happen, to avoid any ambiguity, one should state either the meeting will happen X hours "sooner" or X hours "later" than the appointed time. It's all relative to the point in time one's MIND is fixated on when talking about forward or back or sooner or later. Good old relativity messing with our cognitive biases. Also I wonder how many noticed the comma in the books title.

This whole issue can be avoided when the person scheduling the meeting just use a standard time zone. Instead of saying "move forward 2 hours" for the meeting, you should always give an exact time and time zone such as 12pm PST, instead of saying "move forward 2 hours from 10am," which is vague and a failure on the planner part.
We always use military time when it comes to training in the military, such as meet here at 0600 sharp tomorrow. We don't need to specify the time zone or morning/afternoon because the audience we are speaking to in person are all in the same time zone and understand what 24 hours clock is, which is why we say be here at 0600 sharp tomorrow. And if we were to change our meeting time for some reason, we would either say meeting time has been changed to 0800 instead of 0600 or somewhere along that line.

In my mind, my perspective of forward doesn't match the event's perspective of forward. From the events perspective, it is moving to meet me as opposed to moving to escape me - therefore when it moves forward, it approaches me and meets me sooner in my timeline.

Which makes me wonder... Does that mean I break the rule of there only being 2 ways of perceiving time? Or am I just using the only two ways available simultaneously?

I think this is affected by my native language (Bahasa Indonesia) where if someone says the meeting "dimajuin 2 jam" (informal form of "has been moved forward by 2 hours"), then it definitely means 10AM in this language. Because "moving it forward" in this language means it's coming closer to you. So, it's going to be earlier in the day. Whereas if we says "the meeting dimundurin" which direct translation is like "the meeting is moved backwards", we get this sense of it being pushed away from us therefore, it will be later in the day. So yeah, I definitely think it depends on the language you're speaking in and also, how the person you speak to views time.

I think I can explain it because I can understand both the 10am and 2pm mindset, though my initial reaction was 2pm.

So for 2pm people we perceive forward as going in front of and away from us. When you move forward you move straight ahead.
Example: When you want to move onward you say "Let's move forward".

For 10am when they hear forward they think it's moving closer to them and past them. Forward for them is closer to them, not away.
Example: When you ask someone to bring something to you you say "Bring it forward" or "Bring it forth".

10am: Thinks of forward as in coming forth.
2pm: Thinks of forward as in moving ahead.

For me, this issue is definitely more linguistic than perspective. I don't think I have ever heard the phrase "move forward" in the context of an event changing time before. In my experience, the phrase is "moved up" for the event being earlier than originally scheduled and "pushed back" for it being later. "Move forward" IS inherently vague, so people don't used it. When I first heard this question posed, I was leaning a bit more toward 2pm than I was toward 10am, but when I asked myself, "What would I pick if the question were 'moved back' instead of 'moved forward'?" the answers was obviously 2pm, which meant that 10am had to be the answer for "moved forward." I solved the problem linguistically, not using any perception of time. I asked my parents, and my mom did the same thing, whereas my dad answered 2pm unequivocally. This isn't to say that the ego-moving and time-moving perspectives aren't real, just that, to me, they're not relevant to this particular question.
